brief_summary.textblock: Elderly, hypertension, diabetes and cardiovascular diseases are risk factors for COVID-19 morbility and mortality. However, the real reason for this is not yet understood. It is well documented that gut microbiota has a critical role in health, particularly in the immune system and therefore, we propose that gut microbiota composition could affect vulnerability and disease outcomes of COVID-19.

detailed_description.textblock: In order to explore this hypothesis, we will analyse the gut microbiota of SARSCoV-2 infected patients categorized according to location: [1] ambulatory (self-isolation at home), [2] ward and [1] ICU; and severity.

primary_outcome.measure: Differences in gut microbiota composition between COVID-19 patients with different degrees of disease severity.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Stool samples of COVID-19 patients will be collected after subject enrollment (single point collection)

secondary_outcome.measure: Differences in gut microbiota composition between COVID-19 patients in relation to mortality.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 3 months.

secondary_outcome.measure: Differences in gut microbiota composition between COVID-19 patients in relation to length of stay in hospitals.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 3 months.

secondary_outcome.measure: Differences in gut microbiota composition between COVID-19 patients in relation to duration of mechanical ventilation.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 3 months.
